Many of the most power hungry devices in our home are situated in the kitchen. The white goods; fridges, freezers, ovens, washing machines, and driers account for a large chink of both our energy bills and Co2 emissions. And while there are alternative methods of cooking, cleaning and washing clothes, we still need our appliances.

However, ensuring you buy the most energy efficient device can make a drastic difference considering the frequency of use and the amount of power these devices consume.

Fortunately there are some energy labels on many white goods that can give you guidance on the eco friendly credential and the power and water these devices consume. These energy efficiency labels are governed by the EU so you can ensure of the power consumption of the device you are buying.

Washing machines and Tumble Dryers

For washing machines the energy efficiency scale goes from A to G with A being the most efficient. The labels also contain other information too:

* Maximum spin speed

* The total capacity

* Water consumption per cycle in litres

* Noise generated

Tumble driers have a similar A-G scale, A being the most efficient. There is also guidance on the labels for capacity, noise and ventilation.

Fridge freezers

The same A to G scale is also indicated on the efficiency labels of fridges and freezers with similar information on their capacity.

Other energy efficient devices worth considering

There are other devices that are deigned purely for their efficiency. These are often far more efficient methods that traditional devices. Eco Kettles are one example. An eco kettle will only boil the required amount of water and is far more efficient than traditional kettles.

Halogen ovens are an eco friendlier approach to cooking too. These heat-up instantly and require less energy than conventional ovens to produce the heat - saving money and energy.

Whether you are a landlord or a tenant, it is important to know what responsibilities you have towards maintaining a rental property and the types of repairs for which you are liable.

<B><I><U>The Landlords Responsibilities</B></I></U>
<br>The <I>Landlord and Tenant Act 1985</I> sets out the responsibilities of a landlord in all short-term residential leases under 7 years in length. The Act provides that the landlord is responsible for the following aspects of maintenance:

<UL>
<LI>Keeping the exterior of the property in good repair. This includes ensuring that roofs, walls, doors, windows, pipes, guttering and drains are maintained and that any leaks or structural faults are repaired.
</LI>
<LI>Keeping all installations or infrastructure for the supply of gas, water, electricity and sewerage in good repair. For example, a tenant is not responsible for redecorating or refurbishing a property when the tenancy ends, but where a property is let out for a term of several years, a provision requiring the tenants to redecorate may be included in the tenancy agreement.

<B><I><U>Responsibility For Maintenance of Furnishings</B></I></U>
<br>If the property is let as fully or part furnished, or with white goods such as a cooker, fridge or washing machine, it is the responsibility of the landlord to ensure that all of these furnishings are adequately maintained throughout the course of the tenancy.

All electrical and gas appliances should be checked for safety on an annual basis, and the landlord should ensure that furnishings are fire resistant, fit for purpose, and are not likely to cause harm or injury.

<LI>Keeping all heating installations in good repair. This includes built in electric and gas heaters, radiators and boilers.</LI></UL>

<B><I><U>The Tenants Responsibilities</B></I></U>
<br>The tenant is responsible for repairing any damage which he, or any visitor causes to the property or which results from any failure to observe his obligation to keep the property clean and tidy, not to smoke or create a fire hazard and to ensure that heating and hot water systems are used responsibly and are not turned off in winter.

Replacement of perishable items such as lightbulbs and fuses is also the responsibility of the tenant.

<B><I><U>What About Interior Maintenance</B></I></U>
<br>Unless it relates to any of the issues described above, such as plumbing or electrics, the landlord is no obliged to maintain the interior of the property or carry out repairs unless the interior damage is caused as a result of the exterior of the property not being properly maintained. For example, where a landlord has failed to ensure that a roof is adequately maintained and as a result there is a leak which causes a damp problem inside the property, the landlord must carry out internal repairs as well as fixing the roof.

<B><I><U>The Effect of A Written Tenancy Agreement</B></I></U>
<br>In most leases there is a written tenancy agreement which sets out the rights and responsibilities of the landlord and the tenant. The tenancy agreement can vary the degree of responsibility which each party has for maintenance of the property, although it cannot reduce the landlord's obligations below the minimum standard which is imposed by the <I>Landlord and Tenant Act</I>.

If the tenancy agreement imposes additional <a target="_new" rel="nofollow" href="http://www.lawontheweb.co.uk/Landlord_Law]property maintenance responsibilities</A> on either the landlord or the tenant, then the parties may enforce these provisions against each other. For example, a tenant is not responsible for redecorating or refurbishing a property when the tenancy ends, but where a property is let out for a term of several years, a provision requiring the tenants to redecorate may be included in the tenancy agreement.

<B><I><U>Responsibility For Maintenance of Furnishings</B></I></U>
<br>If the property is let as fully or part furnished, or with white goods such as a cooker, fridge or washing machine, it is the responsibility of the landlord to ensure that all of these furnishings are adequately maintained throughout the course of the tenancy.

All electrical and gas appliances should be checked for safety on an annual basis, and the landlord should ensure that furnishings are fire resistant, fit for purpose, and are not likely to cause harm or injury.

The term can also refer to household appliances which are factory-finished in white enamel, such as stove, refrigerator, dishwasher, and water heater can all be called white goods.

These abovementioned items are among the goods sold during department store "White Sales" which means retailer goods are sold at discounted prices to increase sales. "Homes Sales" however include both groups of household products.

The utility bills that have to be paid on a monthly basis can really swallow up a substantial part of the monthly budget. Do not fret though because there are plenty of ways in which you can reduce them.

The main cost of your utility bills is going to be because of heating your property, and with this being the case it is important that should you have a really old heating system then you replace it with a newer one. It also pays to seal up any draughts, where heat is being lost.

Approximately a third of the heat in a property can be lost through the roof, if a property is not insulated properly. With this being the case it is important to have fully functioning loft insulation. Also, don't use every single radiator in a property when you have the heating on. The radiators in spare rooms and rooms not in use do not need to be used.

Should you live in a warm climate then it is beneficial to use ceiling mounted fans as opposed to keeping an air conditioning unit running all the time. This will save you considerable amounts of money. Take advantage of the winter sun by letting the direct light in which can heat a room up remarkably well. A lot of warmth can be provided by using this technique and it is completely cost free.

If you have old appliances then you need to be replacing them. Although white-goods are not cheap, it will work out far cheaper in the long haul to get new ones. An example of the savings to be made is the fact that an old refrigerator costs £150,00 more to run pre year, than a new one does.

Insulation for both your hot water tank and your pipes is of the utmost importance as so much heat is wasted by not doing this. that way you can be sure that you are running them as efficiently as possible.
